title: E field of distribution - 180-degree arc - E at C

content.question: A semicircular arc of charge <math alttext="positive uppercase Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></math> has a radius <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> and subtends an angle of <math alttext="180" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>180</mn></math> degrees about Point <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>, as shown in the figure. The charge is distributed uniformly around the arc. Which of the following claims about the electric field at Point <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> is correct, and what evidence or reasoning helps support the claim?

choices.label: The electric field is zero at Point <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>. Because of symmetry, at Point <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> there is no preferred direction for a nonzero field to point.

The electric field is zero at Point <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>. Contributions to the electric field from the top half of the arc cancel the field contributions from the bottom half of the arc.

The electric field has a nonzero magnitude at Point <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>. The field at Point <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> is the same as the field of a positive point charge <math alttext="positive uppercase Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></math> located a distance <math alttext="R over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math> to the left of Point <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>.

The electric field has a nonzero magnitude at Point <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>. Every point on the arc produces a field at Point <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> that cancels the vertical, but not the horizontal, field component from another point on the arc.

content.answer: The electric field has a nonzero magnitude at Point <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>. Every point on the arc produces a field at Point <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> that cancels the vertical, but not the horizontal, field component from another point on the arc.
